### Sneaky2FA PhaaS kit now uses redteamers' Browser-in-the-Browser attack


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The article discusses the evolution of the Sneaky2FA Phishing-as-a-Service (PhaaS) kit, which has now integrated the more sophisticated Browser-in-the-Browser (BitB) attack technique, originally a tactic used by red team security testers. This method improves the effectiveness of phishing campaigns by creating fake browser windows that closely mimic legitimate authentication prompts, tricking users into disclosing their credentials even with two-factor authentication protections. The Sneaky2FA kit's adoption of the BitB tactic

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/sneaky2fa-phaas-kit-now-uses-redteamers-browser-in-the-browser-attack/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_3827)**

### Anatomy of an Akira Ransomware Attack: When a Fake CAPTCHA Led to 42 Days of Compromise


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The article "Anatomy of an Akira Ransomware Attack: When a Fake CAPTCHA Led to 42 Days of Compromise" details a cybersecurity incident where a fake CAPTCHA was used as a social engineering tactic to launch the Akira ransomware attack. This attack compromised an organization's network over a span of 42 days. The hackers employed the fake CAPTCHA to lure users into clicking malicious links, facilitating unauthorized access and subsequent encryption of critical data. The article underscores the sophistication of current ransomware techniques and the

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/fake-captcha-to-compromise/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_8165)**

### A Surveillance Mandate Disguised As Child Safety: Why the GUARD Act Won't Keep Us Safe


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The article critiques the GUARD Act, arguing that while it is presented as a measure to enhance child safety, it essentially functions as a surveillance tool that poses significant privacy risks. The author suggests that the Act's provisions enable government overreach by increasing surveillance capabilities ostensibly to protect children, but in reality, could lead to broader privacy infringements for the general population. Furthermore, the article posits that the Act fails to effectively address the root issues of child safety and instead potentially compromises civil liberties without delivering

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2025/11/surveillance-mandate-disguised-child-safety-why-guard-act-wont-keep-us-safe?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_4063)**

### Vulnerability Allowed Scraping of 3.5 Billion WhatsApp Accounts


üõ°Ô∏è **SECURITY ALERT**


A recent security vulnerability exposed the phone numbers of approximately 3.5 billion WhatsApp users, raising significant privacy concerns. The flaw allowed unauthorized individuals to scrape user data from the messaging platform, potentially leading to phishing attacks, identity theft, or other malicious activities. Although WhatsApp reportedly fixed the issue, the incident underscores the ongoing challenges of maintaining user privacy and data security in popular social media and messaging applications. Experts advise users to remain vigilant, update their app regularly, and employ additional security measures to protect

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.securityweek.com/vulnerability-allowed-scraping-of-3-5-billion-whatsapp-accounts/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_7792)**

### Lawsuit Challenges San Jose‚Äôs Warrantless ALPR Mass Surveillance


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The article discusses a lawsuit challenging San Jose's use of Automated License Plate Readers (ALPR), which collect mass surveillance data without warrants. The suit argues that this practice violates privacy rights and lacks adequate safeguards to prevent misuse. Civil rights advocates contend that the indiscriminate data collection can lead to over-policing and threatens individual freedoms, as it captures information on both suspects and law-abiding citizens alike. The lawsuit seeks to impose stricter regulations on ALPR technology to ensure constitutional protections and prevent potential abuse

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.eff.org/press/releases/lawsuit-challenges-san-joses-warrantless-alpr-mass-surveillance?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_905)**
